feed.title: NewsTracker: ebola
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Test shows new Liberian Ebola case similar to earlier virus
entry.summary: DAKAR/GENEVA Tests on the Ebola virus that claimed Liberia's first victim since it was declared Ebola-free in May showed it was closely related to an earlier Liberian strain, the World Health Organization and a health official said on Friday.

entry.title: Mystery of new Liberian Ebola case raised by test
entry.summary: The home of Abraham Memaigar, one of two persons confirmed to be infected with Ebola, in Nedowein, Liberia.

entry.title: Loss of health staff could increase maternal mortality in Ebola-hit countries: World Bank
entry.summary:
The loss of health workers to Ebola could increase maternal mortality in Guinea by 38 percent, 74 percent in Sierra Leone and more than 100 percent in Liberia, the bank said in a report.

"The loss of health workers to Ebola could increase maternal deaths up to rates last seen in these countries 15-20 years ago," Markus Goldstein, lead economist at the World Bank, said in a statement.

entry.title: World Health Organisation slammed on Ebola response
entry.summary:
London: Experts have recommended urgent, root-and-branch changes to the World Health Organisation after an inadequate response to West Africa's vast and deadly Ebola outbreak.

The house where the 17-year-old lived before he died of Ebola.

Ebola health workers spray disinfectant on an ambulance that was used to transport two people suspected of having the Ebola virus on the outskirts of Monrovia earlier this month.

entry.title: Initial Ebola test on Liberia dog carcass negative: sources
entry.summary: DAKAR A dead dog suspected of being the possible source for the re-emergence of Ebola in Liberia has tested negative for the disease, two health officials said on Tuesday, quoting initial findings.

entry.title: Panel: Politics among reasons for botched UN Ebola response
entry.summary:
A panel commissioned by the World Health Organization to assess its bungled response to the world's biggest Ebola outbreak said the crisis exposed the agency's "organizational failings" and called for WHO to be held accountable.

In its final report issued on Tuesday, July 7, 2015 the panel said WHO's sluggish efforts to contain Ebola were partly explained by "a hope that the crisis could be managed by good diplomacy."

entry.title: Panel: Politics among reasons for botched UN Ebola response
entry.summary: But Liu said it was still disconcerting that the panel and other such groups were laying out the world's lessons learned as Ebola was still claiming more victims every week.

entry.title: Liberia works to contain Ebola, find source of new cases
entry.summary: "We will contain it quickly because of where we are in the learning curve as far as Ebola is concerned," said Dr. Philip Ireland at the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in the capital, Monrovia.

entry.title: 2nd Ebola case declared in Liberia as health workers protest
2nd Ebola case declared in Liberia as health workers protest
entry.summary:
Health Minister Bernice Dahn said Liberia has paid hazard benefits to "99 percent" of people who worked in the Ebola treatment units in addition to their regular salaries.

Also Wednesday, workers exhumed the body of the 17-year-old male student whose infection, detected after his death, sparked fears of the return of Ebola to Liberia.

entry.title: Liberia quarantines an area where new Ebola case appeared
entry.summary:
Health workers leave after they took a blood specimen from a child to test for the Ebola virus in a area were a 17-year old boy died from the virus on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia, Tuesday, June 30, 2015.

Liberian authorities on Tuesday quarantined an area where the corpse of the boy was found, sparking fears this West African country could face another outbreak of the disease nearly two months after being declared Ebola-free.

entry.title: Liberia quarantines community where corpse tested for Ebola
entry.summary: The corpse of a 17-year-old man has tested positive for Ebola in Liberia, but no other cases have been reported, the country's deputy health minister said late Monday, June 29, 2015.

entry.title: Liberia reports first Ebola death since country declared free of virus
entry.summary: "A 17-year-old corpse was tested positive for Ebola virus. This took place in Margibi County. There is no need to panic. The corpse has been buried and our contact tracing has started work," said Nyenswah.

entry.title: Liberia announces fresh Ebola death
entry.summary:
A health worker injects a woman with an Ebola vaccine during a trial in Monrovia, February 2, 2015.

MONROVIA A Liberian has died of Ebola in the first recorded case since the country at the heart of an epidemic was declared free of the virus on May 9, Deputy Health Minister Tolbert Nyenswah said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Rapid-detection Ebola test could be game-changer
entry.summary:
A new rapid-detection test that diagnoses Ebola within minutes could improve treatment of the deadly virus and help health care workers contain outbreaks, researchers say.

At two treatment centers in Sierra Leone, 106 people suspected of having Ebola underwent both rapid-detection and conventional testing in February.

The rapid-detection test accurately diagnosed all confirmed cases of Ebola, the study published June 25 in The Lancet found.

entry.title: Tekmira says Ebola drug unlikely to work in study
entry.summary:
The company has been studying the drug in Ebola patients in Sierra Leone.

Tekmira is also running an early-stage trial of a drug called TKM-Ebola, which targets a slightly different strain of the virus.

entry.title: Need a miracle cure? Visit North Korea: Impoverished nation claims it has antidote for MERS, Ebola and AIDS
entry.summary: The authoritarian, impoverished nation better known for pursuing a nuclear program despite global criticism announced Friday it has a drug that can prevent and cure MERS, Ebola, SARS and AIDS.

entry.title: North Korea claims 'cure' for Mers, Aids and Ebola
entry.summary: The authoritarian, impoverished nation announced it has a drug that can prevent and cure Mers, Ebola, Sars and Aids.

entry.title: City paid $30K to settle Ebola fears lawsuit over girl, 7
entry.summary:
(AP) - The insurance carrier for a Connecticut city paid $30,000 to settle a lawsuit filed by the family of a third-grader who was barred from school for several days because of Ebola fears.

The girl showed no symptoms of Ebola and Nigeria had no known cases of the virus.

entry.title: Ebola could hit again and we would hardly do better: MSF
entry.summary: "The reality today is if Ebola were to hit on scale it did in August and September, we would hardly do much better than we did the last time around," Joanne Liu said on the sidelines of a meeting on Ebola in Dakar.

entry.title: Sierra Leone imposes Ebola curfew for northern districts
entry.summary: FREETOWN Sierra Leone is introducing new curfews for two northern districts after a spike in new Ebola cases to the highest level in months, President Ernest Bai Koroma said on Friday.
